elements.content: Herein we report the first example of a metal–organic framework (MOF) in which the location of Li+ ions trapped in the porous confinement can be unambiguously defined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Furthermore, the Li+-doped MOF shows significant enhancement in gas uptake as well as selective adsorption of CO2 over CH4.
elements.clean_text: Herein we report the first example of a metal-organic framework (MOF) in which the location of Li+ ions trapped in the porous confinement can be unambiguously defined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Furthermore, the Li+-doped MOF shows significant enhancement in gas uptake as well as selective adsorption of CO2 over CH4.

elements.content:
The crystallographic location of Li+ ions trapped in a Li+-doped metal−organic framework is unambiguously defined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction for the first time.

The effective introduction of Li+ ions into porous materials can provide Li+-doped analogues with improved performance. The lack of long-range order in traditional porous materials such as mesoporous silica and activated carbon makes its very difficult to understand the relationship between Li+ ions and their performance. In contrast, the highly crystalline nature of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), allows us to determine the structure at the molecular level and readily elucidate specific structure–performance correlations. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) and synchrotron powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) are the effective and powerful techniques used for the direct crystallographic observation of the skeletal structure and even guests within the porous confinement. The remarkable work by Fujita and co-workers indicated that porous coordination networks could be used as “crystalline sponges” for capturing and unambiguously determining the ordered guests on the nanogram-to-microgram scale. Similarly, organometallic guests were immobilized within the porous confinement to provide a way to sequester gas molecules, otherwise not possible, and studied using a combination of in situ spectroscopic techniques. In addition, the dynamic gas adsorption behaviors within MOFs have also been revealed by SCXRD to obtain detailed information on potential adsorption sites. These larger guests are easily stabilized in the pores or MOF skeletons by means of coordination, π–π packing, or hydrogen bonding. However, the unambiguous identification of smaller guest molecules such as Li+ ions is still a major issue.
elements.clean_text:
The crystallographic location of Li+ ions trapped in a Li+-doped metal-organic framework is unambiguously defined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction for the first time.

The effective introduction of Li+ ions into porous materials can provide Li+-doped analogues with improved performance. The lack of long-range order in traditional porous materials such as mesoporous silica and activated carbon makes its very difficult to understand the relationship between Li+ ions and their performance. In contrast, the highly crystalline nature of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), allows us to determine the structure at the molecular level and readily elucidate specific structure-performance correlations. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) and synchrotron powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) are the effective and powerful techniques used for the direct crystallographic observation of the skeletal structure and even guests within the porous confinement. The remarkable work by Fujita and co-workers indicated that porous coordination networks could be used as "crystalline sponges" for capturing and unambiguously determining the ordered guests on the nanogram-to-microgram scale. Similarly, organometallic guests were immobilized within the porous confinement to provide a way to sequester gas molecules, otherwise not possible, and studied using a combination of in situ spectroscopic techniques. In addition, the dynamic gas adsorption behaviors within MOFs have also been revealed by SCXRD to obtain detailed information on potential adsorption sites. These larger guests are easily stabilized in the pores or MOF skeletons by means of coordination, π-π packing, or hydrogen bonding. However, the unambiguous identification of smaller guest molecules such as Li+ ions is still a major issue.

elements.content: Recent theoretical and experimental studies have demonstrated that Li+-doped MOFs can significantly increase their gas adsorption capacity and enthalpy because of strong interactions between the exposed Li+ sites and gas molecules. In most cases, the incorporated Li+ ions within MOF pores are highly disordered. Although Schröder and co-workers used the postsynthetic Li+ exchange method to trigger a series of isostructural In3+-MOFs to neutral ones and further determined the precise locations of exchanged Li+ ions by SCXRD for the first time, the Li+ ions in the corresponding desolvated materials remain partially exposed and are anchored with two O atoms from the carboxylate groups, resulting in a reduction of the accessibility toward Li+ ions and gas molecules. Therefore, the design and construction of a Li+-doped MOF is highly desirable, where the location of Li+ can be unambiguously determined to understand the relationship between Li+ ions and the associated performance.
elements.clean_text: Recent theoretical and experimental studies have demonstrated that Li+-doped MOFs can significantly increase their gas adsorption capacity and enthalpy because of strong interactions between the exposed Li+ sites and gas molecules. In most cases, the incorporated Li+ ions within MOF pores are highly disordered. Although Schröder and co-workers used the postsynthetic Li+ exchange method to trigger a series of isostructural In3+-MOFs to neutral ones and further determined the precise locations of exchanged Li+ ions by SCXRD for the first time, the Li+ ions in the corresponding desolvated materials remain partially exposed and are anchored with two O atoms from the carboxylate groups, resulting in a reduction of the accessibility toward Li+ ions and gas molecules. Therefore, the design and construction of a Li+-doped MOF is highly desirable, where the location of Li+ can be unambiguously determined to understand the relationship between Li+ ions and the associated performance.

elements.content: The difficulty in obtaining SCXRD data for Li+-doped MOFs is probably attributed to the following issues: (i) Li is a light metal and possesses one of the lowest densities (0.534 g cm–3), which renders the ions highly disordered within the MOF pores; (ii) diminished crystal quality or poor crystallinity as a result of cation exchange. Herein, we describe a 3D anionic MOF, {[DMAM]­[Cu3(μ3-OH)­(PyC)3]·S} n (DMAM@1; DMAM = Me2NH2 +, H2PyC = 4-pyrazolecarboxylic acid, and S = unassigned free solvent guests; CCDC 1551768), and a Li+-doped analogue with the formula {Li­[Cu3(μ3-OH)­(PyC)3]·S} n (Li@1; CCDC 1551769) was successfully obtained by a simple cation exchange. Interestingly, the doped Li+ ions are stabilized via Li···O interactions in the pores, which represents the first example of a Li+-doped porous material where the location of the Li+ ions can be unambiguously determined using SCXRD. In addition, the related gas (H2, CO2, and CH4) adsorption behaviors have also been investigated. Compared to the pristine DMAM@1, Li@1 exhibits significantly enhanced gas uptake and selectivity of CO2 over CH4.
elements.clean_text: The difficulty in obtaining SCXRD data for Li+-doped MOFs is probably attributed to the following issues: (i) Li is a light metal and possesses one of the lowest densities (0.534 g cm-3), which renders the ions highly disordered within the MOF pores; (ii) diminished crystal quality or poor crystallinity as a result of cation exchange. Herein, we describe a 3D anionic MOF, {[DMAM][Cu3(μ3-OH)(PyC)3]⋅S} n  (DMAM@1; DMAM = Me2NH2 +, H2PyC = 4-pyrazolecarboxylic acid, and S = unassigned free solvent guests; CCDC 1551768), and a Li+-doped analogue with the formula {Li[Cu3(μ3-OH)(PyC)3]⋅S} n  (Li@1; CCDC 1551769) was successfully obtained by a simple cation exchange. Interestingly, the doped Li+ ions are stabilized via Li⋅⋅⋅O interactions in the pores, which represents the first example of a Li+-doped porous material where the location of the Li+ ions can be unambiguously determined using SCXRD. In addition, the related gas (H2, CO2, and CH4) adsorption behaviors have also been investigated. Compared to the pristine DMAM@1, Li@1 exhibits significantly enhanced gas uptake and selectivity of CO2 over CH4.

elements.content: The solvothermal reaction of Cu­(NO3)2 and H2PyC in the presence of MgCl2 in a solvent mixture of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF)/dimethylacetamide (DMA)/N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) at 100 °C affords dark-blue single crystals of DMAM@1. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry showed no obvious detection of Mg in DMAM@1, suggesting that Mg2+ acts as a template for the formation of DMAM@1 (Figure S1). In addition, the starting materials heated without MgCl2 resulted in an unknown phase ( and b). Furthermore, PXRD confirmed that Mg­(NO3)2 or Mg­(OAc)2 could also be utilized to direct the synthesis of DMAM@1 instead of MgCl2 (Figure S2). These observations indicate that this MOF could only be obtained in the presence of Mg2+, inferring the possibility of a Mg2+-templated mechanism.
elements.clean_text: The solvothermal reaction of Cu(NO3)2 and H2PyC in the presence of MgCl2 in a solvent mixture of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF)/dimethylacetamide (DMA)/N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) at 100 °C affords dark-blue single crystals of DMAM@1. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry showed no obvious detection of Mg in DMAM@1, suggesting that Mg2+ acts as a template for the formation of DMAM@1 (Figure S1). In addition, the starting materials heated without MgCl2 resulted in an unknown phase ( and b). Furthermore, PXRD confirmed that Mg(NO3)2 or Mg(OAc)2 could also be utilized to direct the synthesis of DMAM@1 instead of MgCl2 (Figure S2). These observations indicate that this MOF could only be obtained in the presence of Mg2+, inferring the possibility of a Mg2+-templated mechanism.

elements.content: PXRD patterns and photographs of dark-blue DMAM@1, an unknown green powder synthesized without MgCl2, and treatment of the green powder after heating at 100 °C in a DMF/DMA/NMP solution of MgCl2.
elements.clean_text: 1  PXRD patterns and photographs of dark-blue DMAM@1, an unknown green powder synthesized without MgCl2, and treatment of the green powder after heating at 100 °C in a DMF/DMA/NMP solution of MgCl2.

elements.content: (a) SEM images and (b) the synthetic process of DMAM@1, Li@1, and an unknown green powder.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) SEM images and (b) the synthetic process of DMAM@1, Li@1, and an unknown green powder.

elements.content: SCXRD reveals that DMAM@1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Fddd and has a 3D anionic framework built with triangle clusters Cu3(μ3-OH)­(PyC)3. Overall, DMAM@1 features a 3D channel with approximate dimensions of 6.5 × 6.8 Å occupied by DMAM molecules (a). The guest DMAM molecules within the pores is stabilized by hydrogen bonding between DMAM and the carboxylate groups of the linker (b). DMAM@1 can be described as a distorted hxg-type topology (Figure S3a) with an accessible volume of 54%. Furthermore, PXRD confirmed that DMAM@1 still keeps its structural integrity even after immersion in H2O for 1 month (Figure S2a).
elements.clean_text: SCXRD reveals that DMAM@1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Fddd and has a 3D anionic framework built with triangle clusters Cu3(μ3-OH)(PyC)3. Overall, DMAM@1 features a 3D channel with approximate dimensions of 6.5 × 6.8 Å occupied by DMAM molecules (a). The guest DMAM molecules within the pores is stabilized by hydrogen bonding between DMAM and the carboxylate groups of the linker (b). DMAM@1 can be described as a distorted hxg-type topology (Figure S3a) with an accessible volume of 54%. Furthermore, PXRD confirmed that DMAM@1 still keeps its structural integrity even after immersion in H2O for 1 month (Figure S2a).

elements.content: (a) Li+ exchange process from DMAM@1 to Li@1 along the c axis. (b) View of the hydrogen bonds between DMAM and the carboxylate groups. (c) Li+ ions adopting a tetrahedral spatial configuration with one μ3-OH group and guest H2O molecules in Li@1. (d) IR spectra of DMAM@1 and Li@1. (e) Dihedral angles between the central triangle and neighboring clusters in DMAM@1 and Li@1. Some of the H atoms and H2O guests are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Li+ exchange process from DMAM@1 to Li@1 along the c axis. (b) View of the hydrogen bonds between DMAM and the carboxylate groups. (c) Li+ ions adopting a tetrahedral spatial configuration with one μ3-OH group and guest H2O molecules in Li@1. (d) IR spectra of DMAM@1 and Li@1. (e) Dihedral angles between the central triangle and neighboring clusters in DMAM@1 and Li@1. Some of the H atoms and H2O guests are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: In addition to being templated by Mg2+ ions, DMAM@1 exhibits an ability to uptake Li ions. Soaking single crystals of DMAM@1 in a saturated H2O/acetone solution of LiCl resulted in the Li+-doped material {Li­[Cu3(μ3-OH)­(PyC)3]·S} n (Li@1; see the Supporting Information). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) confirms the similarities in the morphologies of single crystals before/after Li+ exchange (a). Further ICP confirmed the degree of Li+ uptake upon digestion of Li@1 in dilute H2O/HNO3, showing that the concentrations of Cu and Li are 96.18 and 3.34 ppm, respectively, corresponding to the molar ratio between Cu and Li being 3.15. The characteristic N–H and C–H stretches of Me2NH2 + in IR spectra of DMAM@1 were evident at 3253 and 2972 cm–1, which disappeared for Li@1 (d). These results suggest that DMAM is completely exchanged by Li+ ions.
elements.clean_text: In addition to being templated by Mg2+ ions, DMAM@1 exhibits an ability to uptake Li ions. Soaking single crystals of DMAM@1 in a saturated H2O/acetone solution of LiCl resulted in the Li+-doped material {Li[Cu3(μ3-OH)(PyC)3]⋅S} n  (Li@1; see the Supporting Information). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) confirms the similarities in the morphologies of single crystals before/after Li+ exchange (a). Further ICP confirmed the degree of Li+ uptake upon digestion of Li@1 in dilute H2O/HNO3, showing that the concentrations of Cu and Li are 96.18 and 3.34 ppm, respectively, corresponding to the molar ratio between Cu and Li being 3.15. The characteristic N-H and C-H stretches of Me2NH2 + in IR spectra of DMAM@1 were evident at 3253 and 2972 cm-1, which disappeared for Li@1 (d). These results suggest that DMAM is completely exchanged by Li+ ions.

elements.content: SCXRD of Li@1 uncovered a phase transition with the cubic space group F4̅3c, suggesting structural changes. Similar to DMAM@1, the isoskeletal hxg-type framework of Li@1 is also built upon triangle clusters of Cu3(μ3-OH)­(PyC)3 connected by six equivalents. However, unlike DMAM@1, the dihedral angles between the central Cu3(μ3-OH)­(PyC)3 and two opposite ones are equal to 58.1° (green), 64.2° (purple), and 89.8° (brown), respectively, while the dihedral angles in Li@1 are equivalent at 70.6° (e). As a consequence of the minor rotation, the single porous channel system in DMAM@1 rearranged to give a biporous array of channels, herein labeled channels A and B, with approximate pore sizes of 5.9 × 5.9 and 6.3 × 6.3 Å, respectively (a). The Li+ ions can be found in channel A, while disordered guest H2O molecules reside in channel B.
elements.clean_text: SCXRD of Li@1 uncovered a phase transition with the cubic space group F4̅3c, suggesting structural changes. Similar to DMAM@1, the isoskeletal hxg-type framework of Li@1 is also built upon triangle clusters of Cu3(μ3-OH)(PyC)3 connected by six equivalents. However, unlike DMAM@1, the dihedral angles between the central Cu3(μ3-OH)(PyC)3 and two opposite ones are equal to 58.1° (green), 64.2° (purple), and 89.8° (brown), respectively, while the dihedral angles in Li@1 are equivalent at 70.6° (e). As a consequence of the minor rotation, the single porous channel system in DMAM@1 rearranged to give a biporous array of channels, herein labeled channels A and B, with approximate pore sizes of 5.9 × 5.9 and 6.3 × 6.3 Å, respectively (a). The Li+ ions can be found in channel A, while disordered guest H2O molecules reside in channel B.

elements.content: The Li+ ions are located above the μ3-OH groups of the triangle clusters Cu3(μ3-OH)­(PyC)3 and adopt a distorted tetrahedral spatial configuration with one μ3-OH group and three well-defined guest H2O molecules. The distances between Li+ and μ3 (O3) and guest H2O molecules (O5) are respectively 2.753 and 2.705 Å (c), which are much longer than the Li–O bond lengths observed in reported Li+-based MOFs. These results indicate that dissociative Li+ ions are trapped in Li@1 rather than Li+ hydrates. The Li+ ions are confined in a “pocket” composed of O atoms, allowing more space for guests. Indeed, the accessible volume increases to 58% after Li+ exchange. Compared with disordered Li+ ions observed in other Li+-doped MOFs, we attribute the unambiguous observation of the trapped Li+ ions in this work to the excellent water stability of the parent framework DMAM@1 and define the small pore size along with the ordered H2O guests in Li@1.
elements.clean_text: The Li+ ions are located above the μ3-OH groups of the triangle clusters Cu3(μ3-OH)(PyC)3 and adopt a distorted tetrahedral spatial configuration with one μ3-OH group and three well-defined guest H2O molecules. The distances between Li+ and μ3 (O3) and guest H2O molecules (O5) are respectively 2.753 and 2.705 Å (c), which are much longer than the Li-O bond lengths observed in reported Li+-based MOFs. These results indicate that dissociative Li+ ions are trapped in Li@1 rather than Li+ hydrates. The Li+ ions are confined in a "pocket" composed of O atoms, allowing more space for guests. Indeed, the accessible volume increases to 58% after Li+ exchange. Compared with disordered Li+ ions observed in other Li+-doped MOFs, we attribute the unambiguous observation of the trapped Li+ ions in this work to the excellent water stability of the parent framework DMAM@1 and define the small pore size along with the ordered H2O guests in Li@1.

elements.content: The permanent porosity of the two MOFs was evaluated by an N2 adsorption experiment at 77 K. Both MOFs exhibited type I N2 isotherms, characteristic of the microporous nature with saturated uptakes of 123.4 and 218.5 cm3 g–1 (P/P 0 < 0.10); Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas were estimated as 334/449 m2 g–1 (DMAM@1) and 656/811 m2 g–1 (Li@1), respectively, indicating that the N2 adsorption capacity of Li@1 increases by ca. 77.0% (a). The pore volumes for DMAM@1 and Li@1 calculated from the maximum N2 adsorption are 0.165 and 0.293 g cm–3, respectively. Clearly, these adsorption results confirm that the exchange of bulky DMAM with smaller Li+ ions can increase the BET surface area, which was further supported by single-component gas adsorption measurements, including H2, CO2, and CH4. The pore-size distribution demonstrates the identical pore sizes of DMAM@1 and Li@1, probably because of their similar structures (Figure S4).
elements.clean_text: The permanent porosity of the two MOFs was evaluated by an N2 adsorption experiment at 77 K. Both MOFs exhibited type I N2 isotherms, characteristic of the microporous nature with saturated uptakes of 123.4 and 218.5 cm3 g-1 (P/P 0 < 0.10); Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas were estimated as 334/449 m2 g-1 (DMAM@1) and 656/811 m2 g-1 (Li@1), respectively, indicating that the N2 adsorption capacity of Li@1 increases by ca. 77.0% (a). The pore volumes for DMAM@1 and Li@1 calculated from the maximum N2 adsorption are 0.165 and 0.293 g cm-3, respectively. Clearly, these adsorption results confirm that the exchange of bulky DMAM with smaller Li+ ions can increase the BET surface area, which was further supported by single-component gas adsorption measurements, including H2, CO2, and CH4. The pore-size distribution demonstrates the identical pore sizes of DMAM@1 and Li@1, probably because of their similar structures (Figure S4).

elements.content: (a and b) N2 and H2 adsorption (filled) and desorption (open) isotherms measured at 77 K. (c and d) CO2 and CH4 adsorption (filled) and desorption (open) isotherms measured at 273 and 298 K of DMAM@1 and Li@1.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a and b) N2 and H2 adsorption (filled) and desorption (open) isotherms measured at 77 K. (c and d) CO2 and CH4 adsorption (filled) and desorption (open) isotherms measured at 273 and 298 K of DMAM@1 and Li@1.

elements.content: Li@1 shows a significant improvement in its H2 uptake capacity compared to that of DMAM@1. As shown in b, the H2 uptakes of DMAM@1 and Li@1 at 77 K and 1 bar are 110 cm3 g–1 (0.98 wt %) and 158 cm3 g–1 (1.41 wt %), respectively. The dramatic increase in the H2 uptake capacity by 43.6% from DMAM@1 to Li@1 indicates a very strong affinity between H2 and the framework of Li@1. The introduction of Li+ ions into the framework likely induces electrostatic interactions along with dispersive interactions. Notably, this improvement is higher than the value of 19.4% between 1-ppz and 1-Li (with coordinated Li+) achieved by the Schröder group, suggesting that fully exposed Li+ ions in this work provide more accessibility to interact with H2 than the coordinated Li+ ions in 1-Li.
elements.clean_text: Li@1 shows a significant improvement in its H2 uptake capacity compared to that of DMAM@1. As shown in b, the H2 uptakes of DMAM@1 and Li@1 at 77 K and 1 bar are 110 cm3 g-1 (0.98 wt %) and 158 cm3 g-1 (1.41 wt %), respectively. The dramatic increase in the H2 uptake capacity by 43.6% from DMAM@1 to Li@1 indicates a very strong affinity between H2 and the framework of Li@1. The introduction of Li+ ions into the framework likely induces electrostatic interactions along with dispersive interactions. Notably, this improvement is higher than the value of 19.4% between 1-ppz and 1-Li (with coordinated Li+) achieved by the Schröder group, suggesting that fully exposed Li+ ions in this work provide more accessibility to interact with H2 than the coordinated Li+ ions in 1-Li.

elements.content: In addition to the enhanced BET surface area and H2 uptake capacity of Li@1, we also investigated CO2 and CH4 adsorption experiments. The CO2 and CH4 uptakes of DMAM@1 are 49 and 12 cm3 g–1 at 273 K and 38 and 6.9 cm3 g–1 at 298 K, respectively. In contrast, those values show a sharp increase in Li@1 to 104 and 22 cm3 g–1 at 273 K and 59 and 14 cm3 g–1 at 298 K, respectively, implying a highly selective uptake for CO2 over CH4 (c,d). For CO2/CH4 mixtures with typical feed compositions of landfill gas [CO2:CH4 = 50:50 (v/v)], the CO2/CH4 selectivities of DMAM@1 and Li@1 at zero loading calculated by ideal adsorption solution theory are 11.76 and 16.60 at 273 K and 9.80 and 10.28 at 298 K, respectively (Figure S11). The values are comparable to functionalized MOFs with high selectivity results. Furthermore, the isosteric heat (Q st) values of CO2 adsorption show that Li@1 has an initial affinity of 27.0 kJ mol–1, which is larger than that of DMAM@1, 23.6 kJ mol–1, at zero loading (Figure S13). In addition, although Li@1 shows outstanding performance in CH4 uptake, its Q st value at zero loading is 24.5 kJ mol–1, which is comparable to that of DMAM@1, 23.5 kJ mol–1 (Figure S15). This suggests that the introduction of Li+ ions into the framework displays a big improvement of the bulk CH4 adsorption capacity; however, there is no significant enhancement in the sorbate–sorbent interactions.
elements.clean_text: In addition to the enhanced BET surface area and H2 uptake capacity of Li@1, we also investigated CO2 and CH4 adsorption experiments. The CO2 and CH4 uptakes of DMAM@1 are 49 and 12 cm3 g-1 at 273 K and 38 and 6.9 cm3 g-1 at 298 K, respectively. In contrast, those values show a sharp increase in Li@1 to 104 and 22 cm3 g-1 at 273 K and 59 and 14 cm3 g-1 at 298 K, respectively, implying a highly selective uptake for CO2 over CH4 (c,d). For CO2/CH4 mixtures with typical feed compositions of landfill gas [CO2:CH4 = 50:50 (v/v)], the CO2/CH4 selectivities of DMAM@1 and Li@1 at zero loading calculated by ideal adsorption solution theory are 11.76 and 16.60 at 273 K and 9.80 and 10.28 at 298 K, respectively (Figure S11). The values are comparable to functionalized MOFs with high selectivity results. Furthermore, the isosteric heat (Q st) values of CO2 adsorption show that Li@1 has an initial affinity of 27.0 kJ mol-1, which is larger than that of DMAM@1, 23.6 kJ mol-1, at zero loading (Figure S13). In addition, although Li@1 shows outstanding performance in CH4 uptake, its Q st value at zero loading is 24.5 kJ mol-1, which is comparable to that of DMAM@1, 23.5 kJ mol-1 (Figure S15). This suggests that the introduction of Li+ ions into the framework displays a big improvement of the bulk CH4 adsorption capacity; however, there is no significant enhancement in the sorbate-sorbent interactions.

elements.content: To further shed light on the H2 and CO2 adsorption behaviors in Li@1, density functional theory calculations were performed directly on the single-crystal X-ray data of Li@1 to access optimized geometries for the interactions of Li+ ions with H2 and CO2. As shown in , H2 and CO2 molecules aggregate around Li+ ions of Li@1. The distances between the H and O atoms and Li+ ions are 2.26 and 2.36 Å, respectively. The binding energies (E bind) of H2 and CO2 with Li+ ions are −10.157 and −26.057 kJ mol–1, respectively, suggesting stronger interactions between H2 and CO2 molecules and Li+ ions in comparison with those of some classic MOFs (Tables S3 and S4).
elements.clean_text: To further shed light on the H2 and CO2 adsorption behaviors in Li@1, density functional theory calculations were performed directly on the single-crystal X-ray data of Li@1 to access optimized geometries for the interactions of Li+ ions with H2 and CO2. As shown in , H2 and CO2 molecules aggregate around Li+ ions of Li@1. The distances between the H and O atoms and Li+ ions are 2.26 and 2.36 Å, respectively. The binding energies (E bind) of H2 and CO2 with Li+ ions are -10.157 and -26.057 kJ mol-1, respectively, suggesting stronger interactions between H2 and CO2 molecules and Li+ ions in comparison with those of some classic MOFs (Tables S3 and S4).

elements.content: Optimized geometries for the interactions of Li+ ions in Li@1 with (a) H2 and (b) CO2. Color code: Cu, brown; Li, purple; C, gray; N, blue; O, red; H, white.
elements.clean_text: 5  Optimized geometries for the interactions of Li+ ions in Li@1 with (a) H2 and (b) CO2. Color code: Cu, brown; Li, purple; C, gray; N, blue; O, red; H, white.

elements.content: In conclusion, a 3D anionic MOF, DMAM@1, was synthesized, and a Li+-doped MOF (Li@1) was subsequently obtained via cation exchange, in which the locations of Li+ ions trapped in the pores were determined by SCXRD. Further, the pore volume, gas uptake capacity, and CO2/CH4 selectivity of Li@1 have been greatly enhanced because of the smaller Li+ ions and stronger electrostatics between the Li+ ions and gas molecules. Further experiments are in progress to investigate the role of Mg2+ as a template in obtaining the hxg-type topology, and exchange of DMAM with other metal ions via a cation-exchange strategy is currently ongoing.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, a 3D anionic MOF, DMAM@1, was synthesized, and a Li+-doped MOF (Li@1) was subsequently obtained via cation exchange, in which the locations of Li+ ions trapped in the pores were determined by SCXRD. Further, the pore volume, gas uptake capacity, and CO2/CH4 selectivity of Li@1 have been greatly enhanced because of the smaller Li+ ions and stronger electrostatics between the Li+ ions and gas molecules. Further experiments are in progress to investigate the role of Mg2+ as a template in obtaining the hxg-type topology, and exchange of DMAM with other metal ions via a cation-exchange strategy is currently ongoing.

cln_elements.content: The permanent porosity of the two MOFs was evaluated by an N2 adsorption experiment at 77 K. Both MOFs exhibited type I N2 isotherms, characteristic of the microporous nature with saturated uptakes of 123.4 and 218.5 cm3 g–1 (P/P 0 < 0.10); Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas were estimated as 334/449 m2 g–1 (DMAM@1) and 656/811 m2 g–1 (Li@1), respectively, indicating that the N2 adsorption capacity of Li@1 increases by ca. 77.0% (a). The pore volumes for DMAM@1 and Li@1 calculated from the maximum N2 adsorption are 0.165 and 0.293 g cm–3, respectively. Clearly, these adsorption results confirm that the exchange of bulky DMAM with smaller Li+ ions can increase the BET surface area, which was further supported by single-component gas adsorption measurements, including H2, CO2, and CH4. The pore-size distribution demonstrates the identical pore sizes of DMAM@1 and Li@1, probably because of their similar structures (Figure S4).
cln_elements.clean_text: The permanent porosity of the two MOFs was evaluated by an N2 adsorption experiment at 77 K. Both MOFs exhibited type I N2 isotherms, characteristic of the microporous nature with saturated uptakes of 123.4 and 218.5 cm3 g-1 (P/P 0 < 0.10); Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas were estimated as 334/449 m2 g-1 (DMAM@1) and 656/811 m2 g-1 (Li@1), respectively, indicating that the N2 adsorption capacity of Li@1 increases by ca. 77.0% (a). The pore volumes for DMAM@1 and Li@1 calculated from the maximum N2 adsorption are 0.165 and 0.293 g cm-3, respectively. Clearly, these adsorption results confirm that the exchange of bulky DMAM with smaller Li+ ions can increase the BET surface area, which was further supported by single-component gas adsorption measurements, including H2, CO2, and CH4. The pore-size distribution demonstrates the identical pore sizes of DMAM@1 and Li@1, probably because of their similar structures (Figure S4).

metadata.title:
Direct Observation of Li+ Ions Trapped
in a Mg2+-Templated Metal–Organic Framework
